title: Suriname - Conflict Data
org: Armed Conflict Location & Event Data Project (ACLED)

bites.title: Map of locations
bite: On 1 February 2021, in Jarikaba, Saramacca, workers of a banana plantation protested over expired insurance policies that have not been renewed by their employer. The protesters also complained about the way in which they are transported to the plantation. They say the buses are too full to comply with coronavirus measures. [size=no report]

On 21 January 2021, in Paramaribo, Paramaribo, a group of young people smashed the windows of a police van after police had ended their party which was in violation of coronavirus lockdown rules. [size=no report]
On 20 January 2021, in Paramaribo, Paramaribo, around 100 people protested against the government. [size=around 100]
On 15 December 2020, in Paramaribo, Paramaribo, artists and event organisers protested against coronavirus measures. Due to the measures all events were cancelled. [size=no report]

On 23 November 2020, in Paramaribo, Paramaribo, fewer than 10 people showed up to a protest against the arrival of the Dutch Minister of Foreign Affairs to the country. The Minister arrived for the 45th anniversary of Surinamese independence from the Netherlands. [size=fewer than 10]
On 20 November 2020, in Paramaribo, Paramaribo, tens of people gathered outside the Ministry for Public Works to protest, demanding months of unpaid salaries. [size=tens]
PALU: Progressive Workers' and Farmers' Union
On 16 October 2020, in Paramaribo, Paramaribo, unknown individuals burned a pride flag that was being flown outside the PALU: Progressive Workers' and Farmers' Union office.

On 6 October 2020, in the Marowijne district, residents of the Ovia Olo village blocked the road with tree trunks in protest against a company which is digging in the area. According to the protesters the company broke the agreement that was made between the residents and the company. [size=no report]

On 2 October 2020, in Paramaribo, Paramaribo, fewer than 10 protesters gathered to protest against increased fuel prices, the exchange rate and overall policies of the government. [size=fewer than 10]

On 30 September 2020, in Paramaribo, Paramaribo, employees of the Ministry of Internal Affairs protested. The protesters say they have not been paid for the months and demanded the resignation of the new Minister. [size=no report]
On 25 September 2020, in Paramaribo, Paramaribo, around 15 people participated in a call for a protest against rising gasoline prices. [size=around 15]

On 21 September 2020, in Moengo, Marowijne, residents of the area protested and demanded the conservation of the former worker-village Moengo, which the government has sold off to private owners. The village is a touristic and historic attraction. [size=no report]

On 8 September 2020, in Totness, Coronie, more than 100 civil servants blocked the road connecting the east and west of the country with cars as part of a protest. They have not received their salaries for the past 8 months. The police intervened and removed the blockade from the road almost immediately. [size=more than 100]
On 7 September 2020, in Totness, Coronie, civil servants blocked the road with cars in protest over the lack of payment for their services in the past 6 to 8 months. [size=no report]

On 31 August 2020, in Paramaribo, Paramaribo, merchants marched to the residence of the President to protest against the measures implemented to prevent the spread of coronavirus. The surge in cases prevent the reopening of the market which will instead be converted into a 'drive-thru' market. [size=no report]

On 25 August 2020, in the Commewijne district, locals blocked a road known as Blakka watra. Locals showed discontent towards the deterioration of the road caused by loggers' truck. The protesters threatened to maintain the road block until concrete actions to fix the road are taken by authorities. [size=no report]

On 17 August 2020, in Paramaribo, a few employees of the Surinamese postal service (Surpost) protested despite the cancellation of the event. The organizers of the official protest cancelled because of the rising number of coronavirus cases in the country. A few employees still stood in front of the government office to ask for a solution to payment problems that the employees have been experiencing. [size=a few]
Around 13 August 2020 (as reported), in Matta, Para, the leader of an indigenous community was killed. His body was found in his home tied up laying on his bed in a pool of blood. 1 fatality.

On 27 July 2020, in Paramaribo, more than 100 employees of the Surinamese airline SLM gathered in front of the Ministry of Transport, Communication and Tourism to protest. They demanded why a Boeing airplane rented by the company is not in use and expressed concerns over the possible bankruptcy of the company. [size=more than 100]
On 26 July 2020, in Paramaribo, three Cuban nationals burned the flag of the 26th of July movement in front of the Cuban embassy. [size=three]

On 10 July 2020, in Paramaribo, a group of police officers protested outside the Ministry of Justice for the second day in a row. The protesters are supposed to get promoted to a new rank but complained that the necessary arrangements for this have not been made in time. [size=no report]

On 9 July 2020, in Paramaribo, a group of police officers protested outside the Ministry of Justice. The protesters are supposed to get promoted to a new rank but complained that the necessary arrangements for this have not been made in time. [size=no report]
On 1 July 2020, in Paramaribo, two thieves were captured by residents, bound by their hands and feet and beaten. 0 fatalities. [size=no report]

Around 14 June 2020, in Paramaribo, a man who was thought to be a thief was held by residents of the Kinderdeelweg, tied to an electricity pole and then assaulted by at least three of the rioters. It turned out that the man was innocent. [size=no report]

On 20 May 2020, in Paramaribo city, bus drivers marched in protest to the transport ministry. The drivers were angry because their demand for tariff changes were not answered by the ministry. They also demand payment of the coronavirus lockdown compensation. [size=no report]

On 17 May 2020, in Brokopondo municipality, artisanal miners stormed the mining concession of Boss Enterprises in the area armed with machetes near Balingsoela. The local miners say that the concession is part of their communal forest and thus they claim to have a right to mine in the concession. Police attempted to get the miners to leave. [size=no report]
On 8 May 2020, in Paramaribo city, the political party STREI! staged a protest outside of the National Assembly against the Minister of Finances, who has been accused of fraud. [size=no report]
On 21 April 2020, in Paramaribo, a police officer went to break up an argument between two people. For unknown reasons he drew his weapon and shot and injured one of the persons. 0 fatalities.
On 20 April 2020, in Paramaribo, a group of angry bus drivers protested against delayed payment of subsidies which they were promised. [size=no report]

On 16 April 2020, in Paramaribo, the number two candidate for STREI! Party was assaulted in his own home. Four heavily armed, masked men entered into his house and tied him up. Afterwards he was left with injuries to his face, body and wrists. The assault was allegedly carried out on orders of the Directorate of National Security.

As reported on 7 April 2020, in Paramaribo, various small riots and barricades have been taking place at night in a number of neighbourhoods in the southern part of the town - Paramaribo-Zuid, Nieuwweer, Ephraimzegen, Abrabroki - despite the coronavirus curfew. [size=no report]

On 30 March 2020, in Kawemhakan village in Tapahony municipality, Sipaliwini district, a group of Wayana indigenous persons barricaded the airstrip in the village. The reason was that although flights to the inland of Suriname have been forbidden to prevent the spread of coronavirus, a flight from Paramaribo on 26 March still took place. [size=no report]
On 28 March 2020, throughout Suriname a curfew was implemented to prevent the spread of coronavirus

On 25 March 2020, in Paranam, Para district, rioters started setting fire to cars and buildings on an industrial terrain after a security guard had killed a trespasser who was stealing scrapmetal. Police was called and had to subdue the crowd, including by firing their gun. During the riot no fatalities were reported. [size=no report]

On 17 March 2020, in Albina, Marowijne, a group of boatswains marched on a governmental building out of displeasure with the decision by the government to close the border between Suriname and French-Guyana due to coronavirus. [size=no report]

Around 15 March 2020 (month of), in Brokopondo municipality, artisanal miners stormed the mining concession of Boss Enterprises in the area armed with machetes near Balingsoela. The local miners say that the concession is part of their communal forest and thus they claim to have a right to mine in the concession. They threatened and beat personnel and destroyed property belonging to the company. [size=no report]

On 13 March 2020, in Paramaribo, employees of the Surinamese Ministry for Education, Science and Culture protested outside of the Ministry against the firing of the vice-director for education. This is the second day of protests. [size=no report]

On 12 March 2020, in Paramaribo, employees of the Surinamese Ministry for Education, Science and Culture protested outside of the Ministry against the firing of the vice-director for education. This is the first day of protests. [size=no report]
On 6 March 2020, several hundred people, among them students, protested against raising costs in the country especially affecting students and senior citizens. [size=several hundred]

On 17 February 2020 in Paramaribo, thousands of people protested against mismanagement by the current NDP government. The participants were workers, doctors, teachers, organizations, and indigenous groups [size=thousands]

On 16 February 2020 in Albina, residents of Alfonsdorp and surroundings barricaded the main road connecting the eastern and western parts of the country, protesting road insecurity after a collision where a resident was killed. [size=no report]

On 10 January 2020 in Saramacca Polder, a group of neighbors set fire to a house where they believed a man lived who had previously shot at a boy and a girl in the neighborhood. When the fire fighters arrived, the neighbors attacked them, threw objects at them, and broke a window in the fire truck. The fire fighters had to withdraw and called in the police to control the situation. [size=no report]

On November 2, 2019, in Paramaribo, more than two hundred people led by the Concerned SLM Citizens Action Committee (Suriname Airways) protested against what they call unfair competition from KLM. [size=more than two hundred]
On November 1, 2019, in Akontu, one Surinamese and two Brazilian gold diggers were shot and killed, two other Brazilians were shot and injured, police say by a heavily armed 13-man robber gang.
On October 31, 2019, in Paramaribo, a few hundred people protested an amendment of the State Debt Act, delivering a petition to the National Assembly. [size=a few hundred]
On October 22, 2019, in Paramaribo, a handful of protesters, organized by the party STREi !, protested against a change in the national debt law. [size=a handful]
August 8, 2019, in Nieuw-Nickerie, a man was shot dead outside a bank. The man was known as a political scientist, professor and local politician for NVP.
On July 30, in Paramaribo, family, friends and co-workers of the goldminer killed on July 28, gathered to protest his death at the National Assembly (DNA). [size=unknown]
Private Security Forces (Suriname); Military Forces of Suriname (2010-)

On July 28, 2019, at Brokopondo , a task force consisting of police, army officials, mining officials, and security guards were at the Rosebel mine, in an action against illegal gold miners. The police used firearms on the miners, killing one, and injuring two, one of whom died from his injuries the following day, July 29.

On February 28 2019, a large group of protesters took the streets of the city of Paramaribo, Suriname, both by protesting in the city center, as well as in a procession of cars driving through the city. The protest emerged as a result of a new tax rule imposed by the government [size=no report].
On February 18 2019, a man was shot and killed by the police forces of Suriname in Albina town, Suriname, after he refused to cooperate.
On February 14 2019, people staged a protest against deforestation in Paramaribo, Suriname. [size=no report]
On January 26 2019, a man was hung upside down by residents of Beekhuizen, Suriname, after he was allegedly caught in the act of stealing something. [size=no report]
On January 18 2019, residents of Paramaribo staged a protest against a new crematorium, because they claim it will pollute the air in the community. [size=no report]
During the last week of December 28 2018, residents of Brokopondo assaulted three thieves after being caught the act of stealing heavy material.
On 20 December 2018, in Paramaribo, Paramaribo, doctors protested in front of the Ministry of Health to ask the Ministry to comply with agreements made about the rates for doctors. [size=no report]
On 17 December 2018, 34 undocumented Brazilian citizens were arrested in Paramaribo, Suriname. The arrested claim the police were unnecessarily violent towards them.
On 14 December 2018, in Paramaribo, Paramaribo, the police arrested 24 undocumented Haitians who were sheltering in a house. Two Surinamese nationals were also arrested on grounds of human smuggling.

On 1 November 2018, in Paramaribo, Paramaribo, Christian groups organized a march from the Salvation Army's headquarters to the National Assembly building to hand over a list of solutions for societal issues. [size=no report]

On 31 October 2018, in Paramaribo, Paramaribo, hundreds of pensioners marched to the President's office to protest against the treatment they receive from the government, including the way in which their pensions are secured. The protesters handed over a petition to the President. [size=hundreds]

On 24 October 2018, in the Sipaliwini district, French police set fire to a working camp on the Maroni river, which was located on the island Singa Tete on the Surinamese side of the river. The fire destroyed machines allegedly used in illegal goldmining operations. The French and Surinamese police jointly went to the area, but the French burned the mining camp after the Surinamese police had left. The government of Suriname summoned the French ambassador to ask for explanation for what they consider a violation of Surinamese sovereignty.
On 16 October 2018, hundreds of protesters in Paramaribo, Suriname, marched the streets to stop violence against women.
On 15 October 2018, people protested in front of the landfill in Ornamibo, Domburg, Suriname, against health problems the landfill has been causing the community.
On 10 October 2018, a member of the Surinamese military shot down a civilian during a fight while looking for gold in Brokopondo, Suriname.

Around 30 September 2018 (as reported), near Poesoegroenoe, Sipaliwini, people of the Matawai indigenous group blocked the road to the village out of protest. They demanded that the government of Suriname honours agreements made about the development of the area and the creation of jobs, as well as give more insight into agreements and concessions made to multinationals that exploit resources in this area. [size=no report]
On 28 September 2018, approximately 50 women protested against increasing poverty in Paramaribo, Suriname.

On 26 September 2018, in the Sipaliwini district, French police set fire to a working camp on the Maroni river, which was located on the island Kapasitabiki on the Surinamese side of the river which forms the border between French Guiana and Suriname. The fire set by the French officers destroyed more than a hundred barrels of diesel and gasoline, a warehouse with food, and materiel used for gold mining.

On 17 September 2018, a group of Chinese businessmen protested in front of the Chinese embassy in Paramaribo, Suriname, to protest against the Fu Jian Commercial Federation Suriname. They demand access to the money they have been contributing to the organization.

Around 5 September 2018 (week of), in Jacob Condre, Sipaliwini, a man who was accused of theft was beaten up by the local 'Basja' - a sort of alderman of the Matawai community - and at least twelve other men. The man ended up breaking two bones and getting several bruises. The man did not commit the theft. [size=at least 13]

On 20 August 2018, in Paramaribo, Paramaribo, students and teachers of the Albert Cameron Institute (ACI) marched to the building of the ministry of education to protest against the closure of the institute. [size=no report]

On 14 August 2018, in Paramaribo, Paramaribo, the union of a hospital protested in front of the hospital to call attention to organizations that are not paying their hospital bills, claiming that this keeps them from receiving salary raises. [size=no report]

On 23 July 2018, in Matta, Para, residents including students dressed in their school uniforms protested against the poor quality of the road in their village by creating a road block. [size=no report]

On 19 July 2018, in Paranam, Para, former residents of the village protested outside the operation plant of the Suralco aluminium company. Suralco's mother company Alcoa will leave the country, and the protesters now demand that the government to be more transparent about the dealing with the company. The protesters also demand that Alcoa cleans up the area where toxic material contaminated the soil. [size=no report]

On 17 July 2018, in Paramaribo, Paramaribo, teachers at the institute for the education of teachers (IOL) protested at the Anton de Kom university against the paralyzing of the institute by the government with their proposed reforms to the IOL. Since 6 July 2018 no classes have been organized in the institute. [size=no report]
On 13 July 2018, in Paramaribo, Paramaribo, teachers protested against the way in which the Minister of Education has treated them during negotiations over a salary raise. [size=no report]

Around 12 July 2018 (as reported), in Paramaribo, Paramaribo, teachers at the institute for the education of teachers (IOL) protested in front of the Anton de Kom University. The teachers are upset at the way the minister of education treated them and the proposed reforms of the institute. [size=no report]

On 10 July 2018, protesters in Albina, Suriname, protested, in front of a Chinese-owned store, the death of a fisherman earlier that week. The fisherman attempted to rob a Chinese passenger, after which the fisherman fell overboard and died.

On 9 July 2018, in Paramaribo, Paramaribo, teachers at the institute for the education of teachers (IOL) with support of the BVL Teachers Union and students of the IOL protested in front of the Anton de Kom University. The teachers are upset at the way the minister of education treated them and the proposed reforms of the institute. [size=no report]
Around 5 June 2018 (as reported), in Paramaribo, Paramaribo, a group of people led by the Next Generation Movement organized a street protest. [size=no report]

On 10 May 2018, in Paramaribo, Paramaribo, police officers protested and drove in a colonne to another police station to demand outstanding payments for hours worked on Sundays and holidays. [size=no report]

On 13 April 2018, in Paramaribo, Paramaribo, a group of people led by the Next Generation Movement protested in front of the Parliament building against the government, the lack of proper health care and the intention of the President to give additional powers to the Vice-President. [size=no report]

On 9 April 2018, in Paramaribo, Paramaribo, people from the Matawai group protested at the station of the Surinamese Energy Company in protest over comments by the minister of natural resources, who said that he and the Matawai people had come to an agreement over development plans where the Matawai live. The Matawai say that no agreement was reached. [size=no report]

On 23 March 2018, in Paramaribo, Paramaribo, a group led by the Next Generation Movement of people protested in front of the Parliament building against government policy and the intention of the President to give additional powers to the Vice-President for the second day. [size=no report]

On 22 March 2018, in Paramaribo, Paramaribo, a group of several hundreds of people led by the Next Generation Movement protested in front of the government building against government policy and the intention of the President to give additional powers to the Vice-President. [size=several hundreds]

Around 22 March 2018 (as reported), in the Wanica district, Matawai people created a road block to close off the entry into the area in which they live to show their discontent towards a deal made with multinationals on logging operations in the area. [size=no report]
Around 13 March 2018 (as reported), in Paramaribo, Paramaribo, a street protest led by the Next Generation Movement against the government and its policies was held. [size=no report]

Around 28 January 2018 (as reported), in Paramaribo, Paramaribo, a large flag of the NPS political party was burned at their party headquarters, hours after a party gathering was held during which the ruling party of President Bouterse was heavily criticized. A security guard saw several people run away.

On 8 January 2018, in Moengo, Marowijne, inhabitants and other people including taxi drivers protested against the plans that the district governor has for a square in the village, including the introduction of paid parking for taxi drivers. [size=no report]

bites.title: Top 10 of assoc_actor_2 by count
bite: PALU: Progressive Workers' and Farmers' Union

bites.title: Top 10 of assoc_actor_1 by fatalities
bite: Private Security Forces (Suriname); Military Forces of Suriname (2010-)

bites.title: Top 10 of assoc_actor_2 by fatalities
bite: PALU: Progressive Workers' and Farmers' Union

bites.bite: The largest admin1 is Paramaribo with 58 reports followed by Marowijne with 7 reports.
The largest admin2 is Centrum with 62 reports followed by Albina with 5 reports.
The largest admin1 is Paramaribo with 58 reports followed by Marowijne with 7 reports.
